Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Parameter Estimation, Data Analysis, and Detector Characterization for LIGO
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research program at Carleton has a history of applying novel statistical strategies for parameter estimation and the analysis of data from LIGO. The Carleton team and its collaborators have made significant progress in developing methods for binary inspiral gravitational wave event detection. The group's on-going research is in the development of programs for even more complex binary inspiral signals, including the plunge, and the ringing of the newly formed black hole as well as supernova produced signals. When detection occurs, parameter estimation will provide the path toward astrophysics, and the Carleton-developed routines will be critical in that task. Additionally, the Carleton group searches for sources of noise that produce deleterious effects. Carleton develops vetoes for binary inspiral-like events produced by local environmental or detector disturbances; the group also assists the European Virgo detector in their burst and binary inspiral veto development, and will continue to do so with Advanced Virgo.

Carleton is a leader in producing future scientists. This project will provide research opportunities to students with interests in physics and statistics, and help to train them to become the next generation of scientists. Carleton students are eager to participate in exciting research, and their interest in gravitational wave astronomy is large. The computational methods developed by the PI and collaborators have had significant influence in other fields, with applications in cosmic microwave background analyses, noisy chaotic systems, and proposed space-based gravitational wave detectors. Carleton faculty, including the PI, are also active in scientific outreach. High school students and teachers are regularly exposed to the wonder and significance of LIGO's research, and this outreach creates much excitement for science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carleton College has made significant contributions to gravitational wave detection and science as a consequence of this, and previous, National Science Foundation (NSF) grants. The principal investigator (PI) and his students contributed in a number of ways to the efforts of the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) to detect gravitational waves. In fact, on the 100th anniversary of the prediction of gravitational waves by Albert Einstein, they were actually directly observed for the first time by LIGO. These gravitational waves were created by two black holes spiraling into one another, creating a new and larger black hole. The remarkable observation by LIGO of these gravitational waves was also the first direct observation of black holes, another consequence of Einstein's theory of general relativity. Two current Carleton students and the PI were authors on the GW150914 discovery paper, while 5 Carleton alums also appeared as authors.

The research team at Carleton College made significant contributions to the detection of gravitational waves by LIGO, and other aspects of gravitational wave science. One of the research activities covered by this grant concerns parameter estimation. Given a detected signal, parameter estimation allows one to describe the characteristics of the system that created that signal. Parameter estimation has been a central research activity for the Carleton College research team from when it first received NSF funding in 2000. Carleton has made significant contributions to the tools that ultimately let members of the LIGO Scientific Collaboration say what masses the black holes had, how far away they were, how much energy was radiated away in gravitational waves, and whether the black holes were spinning or not.

Another important contribution to LIGO science and gravitational wave detection by Carleton College concerns validating the quality of the LIGO data. The Carleton team uses different techniques to identify specific periods of time when noise is adversely affecting the quality of the LIGO data. Techniques have been developed to ameliorate the data, or veto it entirely. This data quality work has proved to be an excellent way for undergraduates to first commence with LIGO science efforts. Over the years numerous Carleton undergraduates have developed many different methods to clean the LIGO data, and prevent noise signals from corrupting the effort to find true gravitational wave events.

A major research effort by the PI of this grant concerns the search for a stochastic background of gravitational waves. This stochastic background would be created by an incoherent sum of numerous noise signals. The sources of the stochastic background could be cosmological or astrophysical. A cosmologically produced stochastic background could come from extremely high energy events happening in the first moments of the universe, right after the Big Bang. An astrophysically produced stochastic background could come the sum of cataclysmic events happening over the entire history of the universe: supernovae, binary black holes or neutron star systems coalescing, pulsar produced events, etc. After the detection of GW150914, it became clear that a stochastic background produced by binary black hole coalescences over the history of the universe will likely become detectable in the coming years. The detection of event GW151226 reinforces this prediction. This PI of this grant was part of the team that produced this implications statement for LIGO after GW150914. The Carleton group is also actively involved in the analysis of the Advanced LIGO data from its first observing run, and those results will be released in the later part of 2016.
